name: Nagata's example

proofs.integral: $A$ is a domain since it is a localization of the domain $R$.

description: Let $R = \QQ[x_1, x_2, \ldots]$ and consider the prime ideals $\mathfrak{p}_i = (x_{2^{i - 1}}, x_{2^{i - 1} + 1}, \ldots, x_{2^i - 1})$ for $i = 1, 2, \ldots$. Let $S = \bigcap_{i \ge 1} (R \setminus \mathfrak{p}_i)$, which is a multiplicative subset of $R$, and set $A = S^{-1} R$. Then Nagata's example is the scheme $\Spec A$. Also see https://stacks.math.columbia.edu/tag/02JC
